Comment: Computer recommends 2..g6 leading to a likely King's Indian.  But this choice looked fine to me, because it was mainly a lesser used "Old Indian" formation.  It forced me to consider choices other than the analyzed-to-death King's Indian.

But here I expected 11...Ng6 and then I would play either 12. Nh4 (following Del Solar-Jimenez Rojas, Santiago 1951) or 12. a3 (following Sasikiran-Gukasian, Canarias en Red prel. 3rd, from 2004), each with a slight positional edge. But this choice by Black looks like an invitation to pick off the h-pawn, which I accept.

Computer rates this move as a mistake, and recommends 17...Rd8 18. Bxg6 fxg6 19. Qxg6 Bxd6 20. Rxd6 Qg7 21. Qh5+ Kg8 22. Nxe5 Rxd6 23. cxd6 Bd7 24. Re1 Nc5 25. Nxd7 Nxd7 with a guarantee of trouble from that passed d-pawn.  If he had played instead 17...Kxh7, I was planning 18. Nxe5 Bxd6 19. cxd6 Qa5 20. d7 Bxd7 21. Nxd7.
